data.title: JACK DEMPSEY'S TRIAL
data.meta_description: SAN FRANCISCO, Tuesday.— Jack Dempsey, the heavyweight champion of the world, has been found "not guilty" on the charge of ...
data.text:
SAN FRANCISCO, « Tuesday. -

.Jack Dempsey; thc heavywciglit

champion of the world, ; Bas been

found "not guilty" on the charge of

having attempted to evade the Ameri

. can military draft during the war.

Mrs. Maxine Dempsey, former wife

of Jack Dempsey, thc champion

heavyweight, boxer, is an csemplifica

, tion "of the familiar truth that "hell

has no fury like a..woman scorned."

In . a fit of jealousy she informed

(he. authorities that Dempsey was lia

ble to, but. had evaded, military ser

vice during the-.war,, and has been in

San Franoigeo.-3g,''testify for the Go

vcrnme'nt""'pràs«Mit.ion ef her former

husband and his manager, Jack

Kearns, on the charge

This is Mrs. Dempsey's story: -

"Those who criticise me for telling

the truth about Jack should picture

me negelected in a small mining town

while he was getting plenty of money

and fame. I helped him when he was

an unknown lighter. Then when he

knew about "Whip'Willard lie divorced

me. . Did I get any motor cars or

pretty clothes as a..resnlt? No. All

I got was neglect. And not' even

when the American Legion beean to

investigate Jack's enlistment did 1 say

anything until one nay after he was

afraid I would' testifv against him, I

received a photograph. I was mad.

And I wrote a letter to a newspaper

saying that Jack was a slacker. That

started things. '

It is apparent from Mrs. Dempsey's

story that theM'fe cf herself and her

husband was riot nil milk and honey.

She tells how tho champion for days

before a fight becrme quarrelsome,

morose, and sullen. Then she relates

with evident relish how on one occa

sion she had hit him. "It was after

his ficht with "Willie Meehan, and he

bad one eye cut oneu. Wc ouarrellrd.

I struck at the bad eve. missed it.

bnt hit the other."

Mrs. Dempsey says that Kearns it

tho only man who can handle the

champion. She adds that if Carpen

ter hopes lo defeat him he must d"

so in the fourth or Pf th round. "Jack

is very strong at first but he has a

bad back which begins to weaken at

the fourth round. Then they get him

filled with strychnine, and if ho gets

past the fifth he is a hard man to

beat."

Mrs. Dempsey said that she had Ker

own recollections of her husband's

fight with "Fireman Jim" Flynn in

Nevada, in February, 1917, when

Flynn.was credited with knocking him

out, although spectators at the time

declared that Dempsey "lay down."

"For days before that fight," she

said, "Jack practised dropping after

a right swing on the jaw. He told

me after the fm ht that when Flynn

hit him it was so ficht that ho nearly

forgot to lie down!"

Tho defence in the trial tried to

shake the testimony 'of bis former

wife, that she onjjr rr-cefrKTiXIO dollars

(£180) from the time that Dempsey

answered the questionnire in Janu

ary, 1918. to December 1 in the same

year. The evidence of telegraph op

erators showed that Dempsey sent his

wife several stuns, and she is said to

have remarked on one occasion that

"Fred Fulton must have hit Jack a*

he jarred 200 dollars loose from him."

The jiidge excluded evidence relat

ing to the period of the Dempseys'
